iterations.failure_reason: Rule hit but no new signatures
improvement_suggestions: Increase the skip offset to move past the entire loop containing the triggering instructions. This will ensure that the bypassed code block is entirely skipped, preventing the repeated execution of the pattern.

new_signature_details.name: queries_computer_name
new_signature_details.description: Queries computer hostname

new_signature_details.name: queries_user_name
new_signature_details.description: Queries the username

new_signature_details.name: dynamic_function_loading
new_signature_details.description: Dynamic (imported) function loading detected

new_signature_details.name: queries_keyboard_layout
new_signature_details.description: Queries the keyboard layout

new_signature_details.name: queries_locale_api
new_signature_details.description: Queries the computer locale (possible geofencing)

new_signature_details.name: stealth_timeout
new_signature_details.description: Possible date expiration check, exits too soon after checking local time

new_signature_details.name: antisandbox_sleep
new_signature_details.description: A process attempted to delay the analysis task.

data.note: mnolyk.exe tried to sleep 906.0 seconds, actually delayed analysis time by 0.0 seconds

new_signature_details.name: http_request
new_signature_details.description: Performs HTTP requests potentially not found in PCAP.

new_signature_details.name: creates_suspended_process
new_signature_details.description: Creates a process in a suspended state, likely for injection

new_signature_details.name: resumethread_remote_process
new_signature_details.description: Resumed a thread in another process

data.thread_resumed: Process mnolyk.exe with process ID 8460 resumed a thread in another process with the process ID 4020
Process cmd.exe with process ID 7140 resumed a thread in another process with the process ID 8356
Process svchost.exe with process ID 1056 resumed a thread in another process with the process ID 2764

new_signature_details.name: injection_write_process
new_signature_details.description: Writes to the memory another process

data.write_memory: Process mnolyk.exe with process ID 8460 wrote to the memory of process handle 0x0000052c
Process cmd.exe with process ID 7140 wrote to the memory of process handle 0x000002b4

new_signature_details.name: stealth_window
new_signature_details.description: A process created a hidden window

new_signature_details.name: terminates_remote_process
new_signature_details.description: Terminates another process

new_signature_details.name: uses_windows_utilities
new_signature_details.description: Uses Windows utilities for basic functionality

new_signature_details.name: uses_windows_utilities_to_create_scheduled_task
new_signature_details.description: Uses Windows utilities to create a scheduled task

new_signature_details.name: antiav_servicestop
new_signature_details.description: Attempts to stop active services

new_signature_details.name: antisandbox_unhook
new_signature_details.description: Tries to unhook or modify Windows functions monitored by CAPE

new_signature_details.name: antivm_generic_system
new_signature_details.description: Checks the system manufacturer, likely for anti-virtualization

new_signature_details.name: infostealer_cookies
new_signature_details.description: Touches a file containing cookies, possibly for information gathering

new_signature_details.name: persistence_autorun_tasks
new_signature_details.description: Installs itself for autorun at Windows startup

new_signature_details.name: recon_beacon
new_signature_details.description: A process sent information about the computer to a remote location.

new_signature_details.name: antiav_detectfile
new_signature_details.description: Attempts to identify installed AV products by installation directory

new_signature_details.name: cmdline_obfuscation
new_signature_details.description: Appears to use command line obfuscation

new_signature_details.name: disables_windowsupdate

iterations.debugger_log:
=== 4376.log ===
CAPE Sandbox - Debugger log: Wed Dec 24 15:15:15 2025
Breakpoint 2 hit by instruction at 0x06C01CEB (thread 9200) EAX=0x40b1be0 ECX=0x1 EDX=0x147 ESI=0x40b1ae8 EDI=0x19cb68 ESP=0x19ca40 *ESP=0x3df8f14 EBP=0x19cb78
0x06C01CEB  8B85F0FEFFFF             MOV       EAX, [EBP-0x110]              
ActionDispatcher: skipping instruction.
0x06C01CF1  83780400                 CMP       DWORD [EAX+0x4], 0x0
iterations.raw_response:
**EVOLUTION_REASONING**: The previous attempt resulted in a rule hit with no new signatures, indicating the rule matched the wrong location within the trace. The improvement suggestion focused on increasing the skip offset.  To address this, I'm focusing on patterns around the ExitProcess call, specifically looking for conditional checks before the call. I've selected three patterns that appear to be involved in a conditional jump before the ExitProcess call. These patterns are concrete to minimize false positives.

**PATTERN_TYPE**: API_CHECK

**CONFIDENCE**: 65

**REASONING**: These patterns are found immediately before the `ExitProcess` call, suggesting they are part of a conditional check that determines whether the process exits. By bypassing these checks, the malware's evasion logic is skipped, potentially allowing it to execute without triggering the initial detection. The use of concrete bytes aims for precision, while the inclusion of cape options will allow for targeted bypassing of these conditional checks.

**YARA_RULE**:
```yara
rule Bypass_Sample_Evolved
{
    meta:
        description = "Evasion bypass rule - evolved"
        cape_options = "bp0=$pattern0+0,action0=skip,bp1=$pattern1+0,action1=skip,bp2=$pattern2+0,action2=skip,count=0"

    strings:
        $pattern0 = { 85 C0 74 12 6A 5B }
        $pattern1 = { 85 C0 0F 84 33 FD FF FF }
        $pattern2 = { 8B 85 F0 FE FF FF }

    condition:
        any of them
}
```
